Necrophilia has at times been employed as a subject matter in films, novels, music ect... The controversial German film ''[[Nekromantik]]'' deals graphically with the subject, also the [[Canadian]] film ''Kissed'' is about a woman who works in a morgue and finds herself erotically drawn to the corpses she deals with. In the 1970's, shock rocker [[Alice Cooper]] recorded a couple of songs about necrophilia, one entitled "I love the dead", and the other called "Cold ethyl". In the 80's and 90's necrophilia was often a subject of songs in the [[death metal]] and [[black metal]] genres. In the [[1993]] music video for [[Tom Petty]]'s hit song "Last dance with Mary-Jane" Petty is seen in various romantic poses with a dead woman (played by [[Kim Basinger]]).
+
[[Romanticism | Romantic]] connections between [[romantic love | love]] and [[death]] are a frequent theme in [[Western]] [[art]]. The [[William Shakespeare | Shakespeare]] [[tragedy]], ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' ends with the young lovers united in death. [[Edgar Allen Poe]] once described the death of a beautiful young woman to be one of the most [[beauty | beautiful]] images. (By this, he was not saying that it is a good thing for young women to die; to him [[melancholy]] and pain were sources of beauty.) Many [[alternative rock]] artists also focus on the connection between romantic love and death, despair, and the occult; in [[Europe]], the most notable example is [[Him (band) | Him]], and more generally the artists of the [[love metal]] movement. A comparable [[United States | American]] analogue might be [[Stabbing Westward]], a [[gothic rock]] band whose songs dealt with [[despair]], [[drug abuse]], [[sexual abuse]], [[death]], and [[romantic love]], often in conjunction.
  +   +
An extension of the emotional connection between love and death is love for a person, which remains after death. Some [[ghost stories]] focus on a deceased person's undying love for a living individual, manifest literally in the form of a palpable [[ghost]] or [[poltergeist]]. While it is considered a romantic image for a person to die "in the arms" of a lover, sexual activity with the dead is usually considered [[taboo]], but has appeared in recent [[film]] and [[music]].
  +   +
''Resurrection erotica'' is a set of artistic sub-genres wherein a person is brought back from a nonresponsive state (death, or a coma) by romantic or sexual love, sometimes graphically physical. An example of this in [[fairy tale]] is the [[Sleeping beauty]] parable.
  +   +
The [[controversial]] [[Germany | German]] film offers a graphic portrayal of sexual necrophilia, and the [[Canadian]] film ''[[Kissed (film) | Kissed]]'' is about a woman who works in a morgue and finds herself erotically drawn to the corpses she deals with. In the [[1970s]], shock rocker [[Alice Cooper]] recorded a couple of songs about necrophilia, "I Love the Dead", and "Cold Ethyl". In the [[1980s]] and [[1990s | '90s]], necrophilia emerged in the [[death metal]] and [[black metal]] genres. In [[1993]], a [[music video]] for [[Tom Petty]]'s hit song "[[Last Dance with Mary-Jane]]" featured the singer simulating various romantic poses with dead women (played by [[Kim Basinger]]).
